reviews.review_msg: An amazing prof; concerned with questions and open to suggestions. Lectures are interesting and he tells funny stories. Definitely a must take for someone majoring in phil, but not an easy elective. Extremely hard marker.

Oddly specific paper guidelines that impair ability to learn how to write. Chose a very high value exam question on a very obscure point in the argument she chose. The phil part seemed tacked on to the lit. I had high hopes and was disappointed.

One of the best profs I have ever had.  Every lecture was engaging.  If you put the effort in, you will get a good mark. He is very intelligent, and always makes a strong argument. I would love to take more classes with this prof.

this is probably the worst professor i have ever had. he was a extremely rude when i went to see him in his office hours and provided no form of extra help.the class seemed like he'd taught it a few too many times, some of the forms he handed out were circa 1993! he ruined a class which seemed like it may have actually been interesting.
Clear, theatrical, engaging. A thought-provoking course; an excellent lecturer.

I had him for XX1 & 240. Probably the most influential professor I've had. I wouldn't recommend taking his class if you want an easy grade (his exams are pretty tough), but if you actually want to learn something about logic, he's a go-to guy. Every time I'm using logic to solve a problem, I hear his voice inside my head - he's my voice of reason.
Overall, a nice guy. Lectures are organized but hard. However, when it comes to papers, he isn't very helpful. He just criticizes it and offers no suggestion.
Very good lecturer, tests are hard.

Horban seems to want his students to do poorly.  He attempts to trick his students into wrong answers on his exams, and I feel that in this particular course, I was discriminated against for my beliefs.  He is charismatic and fun, but unfair, even mean.
Lectures were interesting, argued both sides well and fairly. Extremely hard marker. Very analytical. Tests are designed to confuse you, not find out how well you understand the course material.
